currentDoc:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them. 
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 the

They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty s
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my o
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also.

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, m

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Often a

Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.

 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Also often with t

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Also often with the surviving memberes

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Also often with the surviving members of their families. W

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Also often with the surviving members of their families. Watching them being emo

They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Also often with the surviving members of their families. Watching them being emotionally distraught

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Also often with the surviving members of their families. Watching them being emotionally distraught is a hard thing to watch. Even more so if they are the children of t

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Also often with the surviving members of their families. Watching them being emotionally distraught is a hard thing to watch. Even more so if they are the children of the people that died from doing extreme sport

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Also often with the surviving members of their families. Watching them being emotionally distraught is a hard thing to watch. Even more so if they are the children of the people that died from doing extreme sports. So, I stand by what  I

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, it really is selfish to pursue extreme sports. The danger and risk involved should be apparent to anyone, even those who think it is a fun "adventure." Do people take into consideration the feeling of those other people who love them, if something terrible happens? No, they really don't. They are only really thinking about themselves and their own pleasure, to which they are entitled by the way, but that doesn't seem the right attitude in the presence of thrills like a high risk of death for example.

People could argue that all sports are dangerous in way. The thing is, yes that's true, but most normal non-extreme sports have an incredibly low risk of causing death. In the event of mountain climbing, you are not only risking your own life, but the lives of the people who you go with because often they are tethered to you with a rope. So not only are you going to affect the lives of the ones that love you, but also the lives of the ones that love them.  That seems pretty selfish to me. Just my opinion on it.
In my opinion, if the own government discourages the sport that you are pursuing because it is too dangerous, then maybe you should listen to
 them sometimes. They do discourage extreme sports also. There was a news story on it, many of them as a matter of fact. Also often with the surviving members of their families. Watching them being emotionally distraught is a hard thing to watch. Even more so if they are the children of the people that died from doing extreme sports. So, I stand by what I say, it is selfish.
